Coyoacán, Ciudad de México 04510, México ⁎ Corresponding authors. Here, we report the impact of incorporating La3+ and Nd3+ into Rh/CeO2 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation at atmospheric pressure. The Nd-doped catalyst promotes methane production, while the La-doped favors carbon monoxide generation. Structural characterization techniques confirm the successful incorporation of both cations into the CeO2 matrix without phase segregation. Notably, Nd3+ is predominantly located on the CeO2 surface, whereas La3+ diffuses throughout the lattice. Quantum mechanical calculations reveal that La ions are mainly situated away from surface oxygen vacancies, while Nd ions are preferentially found near these defects, which aligns with the experimental observations. In situ FTIR analysis shows that CO2 adsorption is enhanced in the doped catalysts, with adsorption intensity correlating with CO2 conversion in the order of Rh/Ce < Rh/CeLa < Rh/CeNd. This indicates a direct relationship between catalytic performance and CO2 adsorption capacity, with the higher surface concentration of Nd contributing to higher CO2 adsorption compared to La doped catalysts. The presence of Nd facilitates hydrogen spillover, enhancing methane production, whereas La restricts this step, promoting carbon monoxide generation from formate decomposition. Quasi in situ XPS analyses indicate that Rh0-CO species in undoped catalysts arise from CO2 dissociation, while in doped materials, they originate from formate dehydroxylation. Overall, this work offers valuable insights for developing more effective catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation, enabling controlled selectivity between methane and carbon monoxide. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 Methanation RWGS reaction Reaction Mechanism Supported Rhodium Catalysts CeO2 Rare earths Operando FTIR Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Climate change and global warming represent the most pressing challenges confronting humanity today. Both problems have been associated with the increase in the atmospheric concentration of gasses with the greenhouse effect [1,2], mainly carbon dioxide, produced as a by-product of fossil fuel combustion to satisfy society's energy needs. Therefore, reducing the amount of this compound in the atmosphere is necessary. In this sense, three main approaches have been proposed: i) to reduce its release through improvements in the combustion processes [3,4], ii) via capture and storage technologies [3,5], and iii) through its transformation into added-value products [6,7]. The last proposal has attracted the attention of many research groups because the generation of products of interest from waste (CO2) represents a great advantage for the development of CO2 recycling technologies. However, the main problem associated with this approach is the CO2 activation, given the high thermodynamic stability of the molecule [8]. Nevertheless, the reactions of CO2 hydrogenation have attracted interest because it is possible to synthesize products above 400°C even at atmospheric conditions when materials based on Rh, Ru, Pd, and Ni supported on metal oxides are used as catalysts [9]. The two main products that can be formed by CO2 hydrogenation at atmospheric pressure are carbon monoxide and methane [10,11]. The former is produced by the reverse water gas shift reaction (1), while CH4 is generated by the CO2 methanation reaction (2). (1) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ C O + H 2 O Δ H 298 K = 41 k J / m o l (2) C O 2 + 4 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ H 298 K = − 165 k J / m o l In general, both reactions can occur simultaneously, but depending on the metal(s) used as the "active phase" and the metal oxide(s) chosen as the support, it is possible to modulate the selectivity [12–14]. Supported Ni catalysts are commonly used in CO2 hydrogenation reactions due to their low cost and widespread availability. However, they are prone to deactivation during catalysis, primarily due to coke formation and the sintering of Ni particles at elevated temperatures [15]. As an alternative, supported Rh catalysts offer higher activity at lower temperatures compared to Ni-based systems [9,14,16], likely due to enhanced Rh ability to dissociate H2 on its surface (an essential step in CO2 hydrogenation) [17]. Despite their superior performance, the high cost of Rh restricts its practical application to catalysts with low metal loadings. To overcome this limitation, strategies such as choosing suitable synthesis methods, optimizing active sites, and tuning support properties have been proposed to enhance Rh-based catalyst performance [18,19]. Among these, modification of the support material has received particular attention, as the catalytic behavior in methanation reactions is strongly influenced by the nature of the support [20,21]. In that sense the selecting of appropriate support material is a critical task, which will depend on the reaction mechanism and consequently the performance of the catalyst [22,23]. Cerium oxide (CeO2) has emerged as a promising support for CO2 hydrogenation catalysts due to its excellent redox properties [24–27]. Under reaction conditions, CeO2 readily interacts with CO2 to form surface (bi)carbonate species [24,25]. While some of these surface intermediates may facilitate specific reaction pathways, others can redirect the process toward undesired products, affecting overall selectivity. Although various additives have been investigated to enhance CO2 activation via support modification, this remains an ongoing challenge. Further research is needed to elucidate the nature and reactivity of surface species formed in the presence of different additives, as they play a crucial role in determining product selectivity. Incorporating rare earths [26–28], such as lanthanum and neodymium, into metal oxides can increase their surface basicity and enhance CO2 adsorption, thus promoting the catalytic activity in the CO2 hydrogenation reactions. Therefore, in this work, samples of Rh supported on bare CeO2 and La3+- or Nd3+-doped CeO2 were synthesized and tested as catalysts for the CO2 hydrogenation (at atmospheric pressure) in a continuous packed bed flow reactor and FTIR reactor/cell to evaluate the effect of the dopants on the formed surface species and their role on the catalytic activity and the selectivity towards CO or CH4. 2 Method 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts The supports were synthesized by the coprecipitation method. An aqueous 0.1 M solution of cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma, 99%) was prepared for the synthesis of pure CeO2 support. For the doped materials, a 0.095 M solution of cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma, 99%) and a 0.005 M solution of either lanthanum (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma, 99%) or neodymium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma, 99%) were prepared for La- or Nd-doped CeO2, respectively. A 1 M solution of NH4OH (Sigma, ∼25% NH3) was then added dropwise to the precursor solution, with continuous stirring, until the pH reached 9.0. At this point, the obtained yellow precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water. The samples were dried at 100°C and calcined at 500°C for 6 hours. The wet impregnation technique was employed to synthesize the catalysts. 1 g of each support was immersed in 50 mL of a 0.002 M RhCl3 (Sigma, 98%) solution. This mixture was stirred continuously for one hour at room temperature. Subsequently, the sample was maintained at 80°C to facilitate solvent evaporation. The resulting materials were dried at 100°C followed by calcination at 450°C for 6 hours. The Rh loading in all catalysts was fixed at 1% w/w. 2.2 Catalysts characterization To determine textural properties (specific area, pore volume, and pore size), TriStar II 3020 (Micrometrics) equipment was used. Before N2 physisorption, the samples were subjected to a vacuum degassing treatment at 300°C for 3 hours to remove gaseous contaminants and/or liquids retained in the pores of the supports and catalysts. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed in a PANalytical Aeris diffractometer equipped with a Pixel 1D detector and Cu Kα (λ = 1.5405 Å) as the radiation source, at 40 kV and 15 mA, with a step size of 0.021 °/min, from 10 to 80° (2θ). The crystalline structure and localization of La and Nd was determined through scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) using a Cs-corrected JEOL ARM200F microscope operated at 200 keV (LUME@UNAM, RRID:SCR_024400). Images were captured in high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) mode with convergence and collection semi-angles of 24 mrad and 68-280 mrad, respectively. The microscope is equipped with an Oxford AZtecTEM detector to estimate the chemical composition through energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). TPR and H2 adsorption measurements were conducted using a ChemBET Pulsar instrument (Quantachrome Instruments). Prior to TPR analysis, the samples were degassed under a nitrogen flow (100 ml/min for 1 h at120 °C), then cooled to room temperature under the same gas flow. TPR was performed using a 5% vol/vol H2/N2 gas mixture (100 mL/min), heating from room temperature to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. For H2 adsorption studies, the samples were first reduced at 300 °C for 1 h under a 5% vol/vol H2/N2 mixture (100 mL/min). Following reduction, the samples were treated with pure N2 (100 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h to remove residual hydrogen adatoms. The materials were then cooled to 50 °C in N2 flow and subjected to successive H₂ pulses until surface saturation was achieved. The Rh dispersion was calculated as the ratio between the number of surface metal atoms ( N S ) and total number of metal atoms in the catalyst ( N T ) by the next equation [29]: (3) % D = N S N T × 100 = V m · S ( L 100 ) / M × 100 Where V m represents the experimental H2 uptake in mol/g, S the stoichiometry (metal atoms per gas molecule, 2 for H2), L is metal loading in %wt. and M is the molecular weight of the metal (102.91 g/mol for Rh). For the calculation of Rh particle size ( d in m), the next formula was used [29]: (4) d = ( L 100 ) f ρ m A m Where f is the factor shape (6 for spherical particles), ρ m is the density of metal (1.24 × 107 g/m3 for Rh) and A m is metal surface area in the catalyst (m2/g) which was calculated according to the following equation: (5) A m = V m A s N A S Where A S is the metal cross section area (7.52 × 10−20 m2/atom of Rh) and N A is the Avogadro number (6.023 × 1023 atoms/mol). The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS UV-vis) measurements were carried out with an Agilent Cary-5000 UV-Vis spectrophotometer equipped with a Praying Mantis diffuse reflection reaction cell (Harrick Scientific). Micro-Raman spectroscopy was carried out at room temperature in a micro-Raman system (Labram model of Dilor) equipped with a 20 mW He-Ne laser emitting at 532 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were acquired using a SPECS® spectrometer with a PHOIBOS® 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer with sub-degree angular resolution (< 0.5°), equipped with both XR 50 Al-X-ray and μ-FOCUS 500 X-ray monochromator sources for Al excitation lines. Quasi in situ XPS analysis of CO2 chemisorption was conducted using a high-pressure reactor for surface analysis applications (SPECS model HPC 20). After each treatment, the sample was transferred to the analysis chamber for XPS measurements without exposure to air. The samples were treated in situ with a flow of 20 cm3 min−1 at 130°C for 1 hour. Subsequently, a vacuum was applied, achieving UHV conditions at room temperature in the analysis chamber (10−9–10−10 mbar), followed by the collection of XPS spectra. 2.3 Catalytic tests For the catalytic tests, 100 mg of each sample was placed in a microreactor coupled to an online gas chromatograph (Shimadzu 12-A) equipped with two columns (5A and Porapack Q packed) and a thermal conductivity detector. Then, the samples were treated at 300°C with 30 mL/min of H2. After the reduction stage, the gas flow was switched to 12.5 mL/min of the reactive mixture (18% vol/vol CO2, 72% vol/vol H2 and 10% vol/vol N2 as internal standard). The gas hourly space velocity was fixed at 18000 h−1 for the studies. The catalytic activity was evaluated in terms of CO2 conversion ( X C O 2 ) and selectivity towards CH4/CO products ( S C H 4 or S C O ) under steady-state conditions from 200°C to 300°C. These parameters were calculated using the following equations: (6) X C O 2 ( % ) = F C O 2 × C in ( C O 2 ) − F C O 2 × A N 2 ( in ) A N 2 ( out ) × C out ( C O 2 ) F C O 2 × C in ( C O 2 ) × 100 (7) S C H 4 ( % ) = C C H 4 C C H 4 − C C O × 100 (8) S C O ( % ) = C C O C C H 4 − C C O × 100 Where F is the inlet gas flow rate to the reactor, C is the concentration of the component, A is the gas chromatographic peak area of the internal standard (nitrogen). The turnover frequency (TOF) and yield (y) were determined as follows: (9) Y C O ( % ) = X C O 2 × S C O 100 (10) T O F C H 4 ( s − 1 ) = C C H 4 m c a t × n R h (11) T O F CO ( s − 1 ) = C C O m c a t × n R h (12) TO F C O 2 ( s − 1 ) = F C O 2 × C in ( C O 2 ) − F C O 2 × A N 2 ( in ) A N 2 ( out ) × C out ( C O 2 ) m cat × n Rh Where m c a t is the mass of the catalyst (g) and n R h represents the number of the surface Rh sites per gram of catalyst (mol Rh/g). 2.4 FTIR characterization under reaction conditions The FTIR spectroscopy characterization under reaction conditions was performed in an Agilent 660 spectrophotometer equipped with a transmission cell/flow reactor ISRI with ZnSe windows. Self-supporting wafers of the catalysts with a thickness of 60 mg cm−2 were prepared by pressing the powdered samples at a pressure of 10 × 103 kg cm−2. Before CO2 hydrogenation experiments, the self-supporting wafers were treated with a 50 mL/min reducing mixture (25 % vol/vol H2 and 75% vol/vol N2) at 300°C for 1 hour. Then, the samples were cooled down to 100°C. For the CO2 hydrogenation experiments, the reduced samples were exposed to 50 mL/min of the reaction mixture (12% vol/vol CO2, 48 % vol/vol H2, and 40% vol/vol N2). At the same time, the temperature of the FTIR cell/flow reactor was increased from 100 to 300°C. Simultaneously, IR spectra were recorded with a resolution of ±4 cm−1. 2.5 Quantum mechanical calculations To understand the adsorption and incorporation of La3+ and Nd3+ on the CeO2 support, we carried out quantum mechanical calculations using the software Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package [30–32], in which the electronic states are expanded as plane waves. We optimized the expansion to an energy cutoff of 450 eV. Projector-augmented wave pseudopotentials were used to treat the ion-electron interactions [33,34]. The non-classical electron-electron interaction was treated using the gradient generalized approximation under the PBE parametrization [35]. The most favored CeO2(111) surface was modeled using a 2 × 2 periodicity for the pristine and oxygen vacancy cases. Structural optimization was achieved when the force (all force components < 0.01 eV/Å) and energy (energy differences < 1 × 10−4 eV) criteria were fulfilled in an equally distributed mesh with a volume of 6 × 6 × 1 k-points. Finally, to account for the highly correlated Coulomb interactions generated in the f-shell of the Ce atoms, we used the Hubbard interactions in the simplified approximation of Dudarev [36] with Ueff = 5 eV (effective on-site Coulomb parameter). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and electronic characterization of bare CeO2 and La- and Nd-doped supports The textural properties of the bare supports were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption at -196°C are seen in Fig. S1 in the supplementary information. In all samples, type IV isotherms were present according to the IUPAC classification, indicating mesoporosity in the studied samples [37,38]. The isotherms displayed an H2(b) hysteresis loop (between P/P₀ values of 0.55 and 0.98), characteristic of ink-bottle-shaped pores with poor connectivity and an irregular pore structure [39,40]. Table 1 shows the specific area values (SBET), average pore volume (Vp), average pore diameter (Dp), lattice parameter (a0) and crystal size for the bare CeO2 and La- and Nd-doped supports. The specific surface area decreased as follows: Ce (76 m2/g) > CeLa (72 m2/g) > CeNd (71 m2/g). As shown in Table 1, the Ce and CeNd samples exhibited similar pore volume values (0.12 cm3/g), whereas the La-doped sample (CeLa) displayed a reduced pore volume (0.11 cm3/g) compared to both the undoped CeO2 and the Nd-doped CeO2. The pore diameter is slightly larger in the Nd-doped sample (6.4 nm), while the La-doped sample exhibited the smallest pore diameter (5.8 nm) compared to the other samples. In the case of pore volume, no significant differences were observed among the samples. Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction characterization of the calcined bare CeO2 and La- and Nd-doped supports. In all cases, only peaks corresponding to the cubic phase of CeO2 were observed [41]. No diffraction peaks corresponding to La, Nd, or their oxides were detected, indicating that the dopants are uniformly dispersed throughout the materials. This also suggests the absence of phase segregation, at least within the detection limits of the equipment used. The incorporation of La and Nd led to noticeable changes in the shape of the full width at half maximum (FWHM) peak at 28.5° in 2θ, likely due to modifications in the CeO2 crystal lattice, which also affected the crystal size. To investigate this, an XRD-Rietveld refinement was performed for the supports, focusing on the most intense peak of CeO2 (28.5° in 2θ) and calibrated using the graphite peak at 26.5°. The refinement confirmed that adding La and Nd caused a reduction in the crystal size of the CeO2 oxide (Table 1). The smallest crystal size was observed in the CeLa sample (8.4 nm), while the CeNd sample exhibited a higher crystal size (12.8 nm) compared to the pure CeO2 sample (10.4 nm). The lattice parameters of the samples, calculated from X-ray diffraction patterns, are presented in Table 1. The doped samples exhibited larger lattice parameters compared to pure CeO2. The CeLa sample had the largest lattice parameter (5.43 Å), while the CeNd sample showed a value of 5.40 Å, slightly higher than pure CeO2 (5.39 Å). This increase in lattice parameter suggests that the doping atoms (Nd and La) are incorporated into the ceria lattice. The larger lattice parameters in the doped materials are likely due to the larger ionic radii of the dopant cations La3+ (1.16 Å) and Nd3+ (1.11 Å) compared to Ce4+ (0.97 Å). It can be inferred that the incorporation of La ions into the CeO2 lattice was more significant than that of Nd. Fig. 2 (a) displays the DRS-UV-vis electron spectra of bare CeO2 and La- and Nd-doped supports. Two signals are observed at 260 nm and 345 nm, corresponding to Ce3+ and Ce4+ species, respectively [42,43]. The bare CeO2 support exhibited the highest Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio of 1.14. The introduction of La and Nd ions affected both absorption bands, decreasing in the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio. The Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio followed the order: CeO2 (1.14) > CeNd (1.09) > CeLa (1.02). In previous work [41], we demonstrated that the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio is related to oxygen vacancies, with a higher ratio indicating greater vacancy content. Therefore, the higher Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio in the bare CeO2 sample suggests a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies in this material. Based on these results, it can be inferred that incorporating La and Nd reduces the number of oxygen vacancies. An XPS analysis was performed to evaluate the electronic changes in Ce ions caused by the introduction of La and Nd. The XPS spectra of the Ce 3d core electron levels are presented in Fig. 2 (b). Table 2 presents the binding energies of Ce 3d5/2 core electrons for the bare CeO2 and the La- and Nd-doped supports. The XPS spectra of the Ce 3d core level exhibit ten distinct components corresponding to the spin-orbit doublet and satellite lines characteristic of the oxidized cerium species. The spin-orbit splitting is 18.7 eV, consistent with previous literature reports [44]. The main components of Ce 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 appear at ∼879.8, 882.1, 885.3, 888.7, and 897.6 eV, corresponding to ν0, ν, ν′, ν″, and ν‴, respectively. Additionally, components at ∼898.9, 900.5, 902.2, 907.1, and 916.3 eV correspond to u0, u, u′, u″, and u‴, respectively. This labeling of these transitions is consistent with that reported by P. Burroughs et al. [45], who provided the first reliable spectra of these transitions. These transitions make it possible to distinguish between Ce3+ and Ce4+ species [46]. Ce3+ species are associated with the transition lines ν0, ν′, u0, and u′, while Ce4+ species correspond to the transition lines ν, ν″, ν‴, u, u″, and u‴ [47]. The relative content of Ce3+ can be determined using the Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratio. The bare CeO2 sample has a higher Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratio of 0.33. This ratio follows the order: Ce (0.33) > CeNd (0.32) > CeLa (0.30). Incorporating La and Nd ions leads to a reduction in oxygen vacancies, which are associated with Ce3+ species, with the La-containing sample exhibiting the lowest value. This trend is consistent with the results observed in the DRS-UV-Vis analysis. The Raman spectra of bare CeO2 and La- and Nd-doped supports are shown in Fig. 2 (c). The Raman spectra showed four bands located at 248, 459, 595, and 841 cm−1. The Raman shift at 459 cm−1 corresponds to the triply degenerate F2g mode of CeO2, which represents the symmetric vibration of eight oxygen atoms surrounding each cerium cation [42,48]. In the doped samples, a decrease in the intensity of the 459 cm−1 signal is observed, with the most pronounced decrease occurring in the La-doped sample. This suggests that the interaction of the dopant metal ions with the oxygen atoms associated with Ce4+ ions lead to the attenuation of the F2g Raman band of CeO2. Based on these observations, it can be inferred that La is preferentially incorporated into the CeO2 lattice compared to Nd. Additionally, it was observed that this band shifted to lower Raman values in the doped samples, with the largest shift observed in the CeLa sample (447 cm−1), followed by the CeNd sample (456 cm−1). These shifts to lower Raman values are linked to lattice expansion of the ceria framework and the softening of vibrational modes when oxygen vacancies were created. However, DRS UV-Vis and XPS analysis revealed that the doped samples exhibit even fewer oxygen vacancies. Therefore, the observed lattice expansion is likely due to the incorporation of metal ions into the lattice. Lattice defects in CeO2 is also evident in the bands around 248, 459 and 595 cm−1, are characteristic of defects that alter oxygen vibrations within the bulk structure [49–51]. These bands intensity and their ratios are reduced in the doped supports, as shown in Fig. 2 (c), being the lowest in the CeLa sample, followed by the CeNd sample, which exhibits a slightly lower intensity than pure CeO2. This suggests that the concentration of oxygen defects (vacancies) is reduced in the La-doped sample, followed by the Nd-doped sample, supporting the DRS UV-vis and XPS results. According to the report by Z. Wu et al. [52], the Raman signal at 841 cm−1 can be attributed to the O–O stretching vibration of adsorbed peroxide species (O2 2−), likely formed at defect sites, which are probably associated with oxygen vacancies [53]. The formation of these peroxide species is enhanced by doping cerium oxide with La and Nd. Notably, the Raman signal for peroxide species is very weak in the pure CeO2 sample, while it is significantly stronger in the La-doped sample compared to the Nd-doped one. An extensive TEM study was conducted to closely examine the morphology of cerium oxide particles, determine the lattice parameters, and assess the distribution of La and Nd dopants. Fig. S2 shows a series of low-magnification TEM micrographs for the bare CeO2 and La- and Nd-doped supports. As observed, the average particle size varied between the samples. The average cerium oxide particle sizes were 13.8 nm for Ce, 10.7 nm for CeLa, and 22.1 nm for CeNd. While the average crystal diameters differ from those determined by XRD, the overall trend in relation to the effect of the dopants is consistent. The difference in the magnitude of the values could be attributed to the fact that XRD is a bulk technique, while TEM, although statistically significant, provides localized analysis in specific regions. The local structure of the prepared supports was determined through HAADF-STEM imaging (Fig. 3 a). From the images of the Ce, CeLa, and CeNd samples, the porous structure of the particles is noticed, with pore sizes within the mesoporous range. Additionally, interparticle channels and micropores can form from the agglomeration of particles [50], as observed in Fig. 3 a. High-magnification HAADF imaging performed on individual nanoparticles is shown in Fig. 3 b. The observed structures confirmed the single-phase cubic fluorite structure, oriented along the [110] zone axis for the Ce sample, [100] for the CeLa sample, and [110] for the CeNd sample. It has been observed that in defective CeO2 nanoparticles, tensile lattice strain is concentrated at the particles surface and pores, likely due to the presence of Ce3+ species and the resulting oxygen vacancies [50,51,54–56]. This tensile lattice strain is more pronounced in the bare CeO2 and Nd-doped samples. These findings align with the results from DRS UV-Vis, XPS, and Raman analyses. The structure of the three samples was determined through selected area electron diffraction, as shown in Fig. 3 c. The bare CeO2 sample, used as a control for the La- and Nd-doped samples, displayed the expected cubic fluorite structure of CeO2. The average experimental lattice parameter for the bare CeO2 was 5.403 Å, calculated from the first four reflections. When doped with La, the cubic structure was preserved, but a noticeable expansion of the lattice parameter was observed, with the CeLa sample exhibiting a lattice parameter of 5.436 Å, larger than that of the bare CeO2. Similarly, the Nd-doped sample (CeNd) retained the cubic structure, though the lattice expansion was minimal, reaching 5.406 Å. These results are consistent with the XRD findings. Thus, it can be inferred that the cerium oxide lattice expands due to the incorporation of lanthanum ions, while in the Nd-doped sample, it is likely that Nd ions are preferentially located on the cerium oxide surface. To clarify the location and distribution of dopants within the cerium oxide matrix, elemental mapping was conducted using EDS. The elemental mapping results of the La- and Nd-doped CeO2 are shown in Fig. 4 . EDS mapping of the La- and Nd-doped supports revealed that the elemental content of the doping elements was 1.85 wt% La and 3.34 wt% Nd for the CeLa and CeNd samples, respectively. The elemental maps show a good dispersion of the dopants within the particle structure. EDS line scans showed a preferent location of La at the particle interior, while line scans for Nd indicate better dopant dispersion and a higher concentration of Nd species at the surface of the cerium oxide particles compared to La. This suggests that Nd is primarily localized on the surface of the cerium oxide, while La is more likely incorporated into the cerium oxide lattice, as supported by previous characterizations. Therefore, based on the experimental evidence above discussed, we can conclude that a significant portion of lanthanum integrates into the cerium oxide structure, whereas neodymium tends to preferentially accumulate on the surface. We carried out a series of quantum mechanical calculations to understand the sites La3+ and Nd3+ may take on the CeO2 surface and their potential role in the catalytic conversion of CO2 to CH4. We first modeled the (111) surface with and without oxygen vacancies; we then adsorbed and incorporated the rare earth atoms. The stability of these structures was obtained through the Surface Formation Energy (SFE) formalism [30–34], in which different numbers of atoms can be accounted for. In this formalism, stability depends on the chemical potential rather than total energy. That allows us to compare several models and growth conditions, in which considering vacancies and other defects is key to understanding the atomic scale systems. Here, we focus on the pristine and oxygen vacancy CeO2 surface. The growth ranges are Ce-rich and O-rich conditions, which are limited by the CeO2 formation enthalpy, Δ H f C e O 2 . Upon adding the rare earth elements, we considered them to be in rich conditions, so we have μ N d = μ N d b u l k and μ L a = μ L a b u l k . First, we adsorb the La and Nd atoms on the pristine (O-T) and oxygen vacancy (O-v) CeO2 surfaces. In the O-v model, we also treated models near and far from the vacancy. After structural optimization, we determined the most stable adsorption sites. La and Nd mainly adsorb in a threefold fashion with oxygen atoms. An interesting thing here is that the second monolayer oxygen vacancy diffuses towards the third monolayer. The atomic models of the most stable adsorption sites (O-v La-ads surface and O-v Nd-ads surface) are depicted in Fig. 5 a. The second step was to incorporate the La and Nd atoms into the first, second and third monolayers of CeO2 to understand the feasibility of the doping agents incorporation towards the bulk. As in the adsorption case, we treated three cases: one near the vacancy defect, one far from the vacancy, and the last in the pristine structure. These models apply to the three surface layers accounted for in the study. Interestingly, La atoms are incorporated far from the vacancy site, while Nd atoms are incorporated around the vacancy; see models O-v La-1ML surface and O-v Nd-1ML surface in Fig. 5 a. Now, we determine the stability of each model with La and Nd by using the surface formation energy formalism, see Fig. 5 b. The right part of the Fig. depicts the SFE plot for Nd incorporation into the CeO2 surface. Notice that the most stable site at Ce-rich conditions corresponds to the Nd atom adsorbed on the O-v surface (O-v Nd-ads). As the growth conditions increase in oxygen content, the stable surface suddenly changes its stability, and now the most stable site is the Nd incorporation into the third CeO2 layer, far from the vacancy site (O-v Nd-3ML); however, notice that the SFE is degenerated with the Nd placed in the first layer (orange dotted line). Finally, in O-rich conditions, one site appears; now, it is feasible to find Nd atoms in the third Ce layer towards the bulk; in this case, such a stable model appears in the zones with no surface oxygen vacancies. Similar findings appear for the case of La incorporation; see the left part of Fig. 5 b. Here, at Ce-rich conditions, the stable surface is O-v La-ads, in which the La atoms are adsorbed onto the O-v surface. At intermediate growth conditions, the most favorable structure is the O-v La-1ML model, in which La is placed in the first CeO2 layer. Also, like the Nd case, the SFE of this model degenerates with the case of placing La in the third CeO2 layer (orange dotted line). Finally, incorporating La in first (pink dotted line) and third (O-T La-3ML) CeO2 layers onto the O-T surface is feasible in O-rich conditions. The surface formation energy analysis evidenced that La and Nd atoms may adsorb at the surface and incorporate into the CeO2 bulk structure; see Fig. 5 b for both La and Nd. To understand the viability of La and Nd atoms to diffuse from the first to the third layer Ce sites, we compare their relative energies. Here, the relative energies allow us to estimate the possible diffusion barrier, which, in this case, is the second monolayer site. Fig. 5 c depicts the energy comparison between the incorporation sites. Notice that La atoms may easily diffuse from the first to the third surface layer since the energies of La into the second monolayer are very similar to the ones in the first and third monolayers. Even in the presence of oxygen vacancies, incorporating La into the second monolayer is also viable so that the La atoms may be distributed between the surface, subsurface, and bulk layers. In the case of Nd, first of all, notice that the energy of Nd into the first and third monolayers only varies by ∼0.14 eV so that Nd can be located easily as an adsorbate and into the first and third Ce layers; however, the energy to reach layer two and further reach the third is almost 1 eV, which means that Nd will be mainly confined at the surface. Although Nd is also stable at the third monolayer, the energy to diffuse it is very large, making it less probable to find it in the third monolayer. Even though it may reach the third layer in some cases, like when there are Ce vacancies in the second monolayer, these results explain why, in the experiment, Nd is observed as a surface species, and La is incorporated into the CeO2 matrix. Finally, we calculated vacancy formation energy by employing the equation [57]: E O v = E s t o i c h i o m e t r i c s − [ E r e d u c e d + 1 2 E O 2 ] Where the first term is the total energy of the system without oxygen vacancies, the second is for the total energy of the system with an oxygen vacancy, and E O 2 is the energy of an isolated O2 molecule in its triplet state. For pristine CeO2 (111) surface, the cost to form an oxygen vacancy is -2.77 eV, this suggests that the formation of vacancies are thermodynamically favorable. About Nd and La doped systems, the E O v is -2.65 eV and -2.04 eV, respectively. Although in all cases, the formation of vacancies are energetically viable. For bare CeO2, we notice the lowest E O v followed by the Nd and La systems. Our results evidence that it is less favorable to generate oxygen vacancies in the presence of Nd and La in excellent agreement with experimental measurements. 3.2 Characterization and electronic effects of CO2 adsorption on Rh/CeO2 and La- and Nd-doped catalysts The nitrogen physisorption isotherms of the catalysts (Fig. S1) exhibit type IV behavior according to IUPAC classification, confirming the presence of mesoporous structures [37,38], like those observed in their corresponding supports. The textural parameters of the catalysts are summarized in Table 3 . A slight decrease in specific surface area (SBET), pore volume (Vp), and average pore diameter (Dp) was observed when compared to their respective support. X-ray diffraction characterization of the calcined is shown in Fig. 6 . As in the fresh samples, only peaks corresponding to the cubic phase of CeO2 (JCPDS No. 34-0394) were observed. No diffraction peaks related to lanthanum, neodymium, or their oxides were detected in Fig. 6, indicating no dopant segregation or that the particles were below the detection limits of the equipment used. As in the fresh samples, no diffraction peaks corresponding to oxide species were observed, then rhodium particles are smaller than the detection limit of the equipment. Fig. 6 shows a noticeable reduction in the intensity of CeO2 peaks for La- and Nd-doped calcined samples (black line) compared to the undoped Rh/Ce sample. The Rh/CeLa sample exhibited the most significant decrease in diffraction peak intensity. This reduction in peak intensity is attributed to the Ce4+ by La3+ or Nd3+ substitution, as evidenced by our quantum mechanical calculations, causing displacement of Ce ions within the lattice planes [37]. The lattice parameters of the calcined Rh/CeLa (5.43 Å) and Rh/CeNd (5.42 Å) samples are larger than those of the calcined Rh/Ce sample (5.40 Å), as shown in Table 3. A slight increase in the lattice parameters was observed in both Rh/Ce and Rh/CeNd samples compared to the lattice parameters of their corresponding supports (Table 1). The crystal sizes of the catalysts decreased compared to the corresponding sizes of their respective supports (Table 1). This decrease was most pronounced in the Rh/CeNd catalyst, where the crystal size was reduced from 12.8 nm for the CeNd support (Table 1) to 10.8 nm for the Rh/CeNd catalyst (Table 3). This reduction could be attributed to the redistribution of cerium oxide particles caused by the incorporation of rhodium and the thermal effects of the calcination process. After the reduction process at 300°C, the XRD peaks of the freshly reduced samples showed a decrease in intensity and a shift to lower angles, as illustrated in Fig. 6. Lattice parameter analysis revealed that the reduction process causes lattice expansion, resulting in a consistent value of 5.47 Å across all samples, as shown in Table 1. The observed lattice expansion is likely due to the partial reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ species, which have a larger ionic radius (1.14 Å). This reduction, promoted by Rh during the reduction step, also results in the formation of oxygen vacancies within the lattice, as previously reported in the literature [37]. Consequently, a slight decrease in crystal size was observed in both the Rh/Ce and Rh/Nd samples following the reduction process (Table 3). The catalysts were characterized in both their calcined and freshly reduced states using UV-Vis DRS to examine the effect of doping on their electronic properties. UV-Vis DRS spectra of the calcined (black line) and freshly reduced (red line) Rh/CeO2 and La- and Nd-doped catalysts are shows in Fig. 6. All catalysts exhibited two high intense absorption bands centered at 260 nm and 345 nm, corresponding to Ce3+ and Ce4+ species, respectively [42,43]. For the absorption band associated with Ce3+ species, no significant changes in intensity were observed in any of the catalysts following the reduction process. In contrast, the absorption band associated with Ce4+ species showed noticeable changes after the reduction of the Rh/Ce and Rh/CeNd catalysts, while the Rh/CeLa catalyst displayed only minor changes in this band after reduction. The decrease in the signal related to Ce4+ ions is likely due to the reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+. The larger ionic radius of Ce3+ may also contribute to lattice expansion, which explains the observed widening of the lattice in the reduced samples. This lattice expansion is associated with the presence of both Ce3+ sites and oxygen vacancies within the bulk of the support, possibly due to surface oxygen from CeO2 being removed during reduction, similar to the behavior observed in previously reported Ce-Ga mixed oxides [38]. The most substantial decrease in the intensity of the Ce3+ species band was observed in the undoped sample (Rh/Ce). The Ce3+/Ce4+ absorption band ratio for the calcined Rh/Ce catalyst was 1.03, which increased to 1.09 in the reduced state. For the Rh/CeNd catalyst, the Ce3+/Ce4+ absorption band ratio shifted from 1.05 in the calcined sample to 1.08 after reduction, while in the Rh/CeLa sample, the ratio changed from 1.07 to 1.08. An increase in the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio suggests a rise in the number of oxygen vacancies. These results indicate that the undoped sample (Rh/Ce) experienced the highest increase in oxygen vacancies, followed by the Nd-doped catalyst. In contrast, the La-doped catalyst showed minimal variation in oxygen vacancies generated after reduction. These results confirm the trend observed in our quantum mechanical calculations, in which the oxygen vacancy formation follows the same trend (Rh/Ce > Rh/CeNd > Rh/CeLa). Additionally, a broad absorption band centered at 550 nm was observed in all catalysts, likely associated with the presence of Rh0 nanoparticles [58]. The intensity and width of this band were slightly higher in the undoped sample (Rh/Ce), followed by the La-doped sample, and were slightly lower in the Nd-doped sample. No significant changes in the intensity or shape of this absorption band were observed in the reduced Rh/CeNd and Rh/CeLa catalysts compared to their corresponding calcined samples. This suggests that the rhodium species remain relatively stable in the doped samples. Table 4 summarizes the H2 uptake values for the reduced samples, which show minimal variation across the catalysts, ranging from 23 to 26 mmol/g. Likewise, Rh dispersion remains relatively consistent, with values between 47% and 53%. Therefore, the calculated Rh particle sizes were 2.1 nm for the Rh/Ce sample and 2.3 nm for both Rh/CeLa and Rh/CeNd, whose presence in the surface of catalyst is further supported by the plasmonic absorption band observed around 550 nm in the UV-vis DRS spectra. These results indicate that the incorporation of La or Nd does not markedly improve Rh dispersion on the catalyst surface. To assess the electronic shifts in Ce and Rh ions environment caused by the introduction of La and Nd dopants, we employed XPS. The XPS spectra of the Ce 3d core electron levels for both the calcined and freshly reduced samples are presented in Fig. 8. The binding energies of Ce 3d core electrons for the calcined and freshly reduced Rh/Ce and doped catalysts are shown in Table S1. The deconvolution of the XPS spectra of the Ce 3d core levels reveals distinct components corresponding to the spin-orbit doublet and satellite lines characteristic of oxidized cerium species. The calcined samples displayed Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratios in the following order: Rh/CeNd (0.35) > Rh/Ce (0.34) > Rh/CeLa (0.33), as shown in Table 4. This trend is different from that observed in DRS-UV-vis results, which can be attributed to the fact that DRS-UV-Vis is a bulk technique, while XPS provides surface-level information. However, it is important to note that the dopants influence oxygen vacancies, which are related to Ce3+ species. After reduction, the Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratio increased in all samples, with the undoped Rh/Ce sample exhibiting the highest value. The Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratio in the reduced samples followed the order: Rh/Ce (0.38) > Rh/CeNd (0.37) = Rh/CeLa (0.37), as shown in Table 4. This trend is consistent with the results observed in UV-Vis DRS. Even though one technique focuses on the bulk and the other provides surface information, the similarity can be explained by the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+. As previously observed, all reduced samples approach their maximum number of oxygen vacancies under the reduction conditions used in this study. From XPS, it is notable that the incorporation of La and Nd ions leads to significant changes in oxygen vacancies in the calcined samples, which are linked to Ce3+ species, while in the freshly reduced samples, it appears that all samples reach a similar maximum level of oxygen vacancies following the reduction process. The corresponding binding energies of the Rh 3d core electron levels for both the calcined and freshly reduced samples are provided in Table S2. The binding energies of the Rh 3d5/2 core electron levels in the calcined samples are centered on 308.2 eV, characteristic of Rh3+ species associated with the Rh2O3 phase [59]. Similarly, in the freshly reduced samples, only an Rh 3d5/2 signal around 307.1 eV is observed, indicating the presence of metallic Rh0 species [60]. As shown in Table 4, the Rh/Ce sample exhibited the highest amount of surface-exposed rhodium species among the calcined catalysts, as indicated by the Rh/Ce ratio of 0.022. The Rh/Ce ratio slightly decreases in the doped catalysts, with the Rh/CeLa catalyst showing the lowest atomic Rh/Ce value of 0.019, while the Rh/CeNd catalyst displayed an Rh/Ce ratio of 0.020, as shown in Table 4. This suggests that both La and Nd promote the dispersion of oxidized Rh species on the catalysts’ surface. After the reduction process, the amount of rhodium exposed on the surface decreased on the undoped Rh/Ce sample. In contrast, the amount of exposed Rh increased after reduction in both the La- and Nd-doped samples (Table 4). The Rh/Ce surface atomic ratio decreased from 0.022 to 0.019 in the undoped sample (Rh/Ce). This suggests the formation of larger rhodium particles, as indicated by the slight increase in plasmonic resonance centered at 550 nm in the reduced Rh/Ce sample (Fig. 7 ). The largest increase in the Rh/Ce surface atomic ratio was observed in the Nd-doped catalyst, rising from 0.020 to 0.022, while the Rh/CeLa catalyst showed an increase from 0.019 to 0.020 (Table 4). This could be attributed to the redispersion of Rh species during the reduction process, suggesting that the dopants promote the dispersion of the active phase. The temperature-programmed reduction profiles of the calcined catalysts are shown in Fig. 9. All samples showed two reduction peaks below 200°C (Fig. 9), which are attributed to the reduction of Rh3+ to Rh0 species [61,62]. In general, higher H2 consumption temperatures in TPR characterizations are associated with stronger metal-support interactions [63]. Therefore, the presence of these two peaks suggests the existence of two types of Rh3+ species with varying metal-support interactions. For the Rh/Ce sample, the peaks of Rh3+ reduction appeared at 152 and 167°C (Fig. 9). Similar results were obtained by Labaki et al. in CeO2-supported Rh samples [64]. Incorporating of La and Nd reduced the amount of H2 consumed at temperatures below 200°C compared to the undoped catalyst (Rh/Ce). Additionally, the reduction peaks associated with the conversion of Rh3+ to Rh0 shifted to lower temperatures. This indicates that the reducibility of the Rh particles is enhanced by changes in the surface of CeO2 caused by the La and Nd doping. For example, the reduction temperatures of Rh3+ in the Rh/Ce sample, originally at 152°C and 167°C, decreased to 142°C and 155°C in the Rh/CeLa sample, as shown in Fig. 9. This effect was even more pronounced in the sample doped with Nd, where the lower reduction temperature of Rh3+ species in Rh/Ce was reduced to 82°C, highlighting a significant impact of doping on reduction behavior. Additionally, as shown in the TPR patterns in Fig. 9, a broad H2 consumption peak appeared between 250°C and 400°C, which can be attributed to the partial reduction of the CeO2 surface [60,64]. This peak was more pronounced in the Rh/CeNd sample, where the reduction of Rh3+ species was observed below 100°C, likely due to greater dispersion of rhodium species. This suggests that Rh sites facilitate the support reduction, particularly in the Rh/CeNd sample. This may occur through a mechanism in which H2 is first dissociated on the reduced Rh particles, and the resulting H adatoms then migrate to the support. 3.3 CO2 hydrogenation activity The materials were tested as catalysts in a continuous flow-packed bed reactor to evaluate the rare earth doping effect in the CeO2-supported Rh on the catalysis of CO2 hydrogenation. The results of catalytic activity in terms of CO2 conversion percentage and yields are shown in Fig. 10 a and 10 b, respectively. As expected, the temperature increment for all materials increased the % CO2 conversion (Fig. 10 a). As shown in Fig. 10 a, the CO2 hydrogenation results indicate that the Rh catalysts supported on La- and Nd-doped CeO2 exhibit superior catalytic performance compared to the undoped Rh/Ce sample. The Rh/CeNd catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic performance compared to the other catalysts. Furthermore, the Nd-doped catalyst exhibited higher yield towards CH4 formation compared to the other catalysts, even at elevated temperatures (Fig. 10 b). On the other hand, the Rh/CeLa catalyst showed improved CO2 conversion compared to the undoped Rh/Ce catalyst, which was more noticeable at temperatures above 250°C (Fig. 10 a). In all tested samples, the yield towards carbon monoxide formation increased in function of the temperature (Fig. 10 b). This phenomenon can be attributed to the differences in formation enthalpies for methane and carbon monoxide through CO2 methanation (ΔH298K = -165 kJ/mol) and the reverse water-gas shift reaction (ΔH298K = 41 kJ/mol), respectively. The highest yield towards CO formation was observed in the La-doped sample, significantly increasing at higher temperatures (Fig. 10 b). In contrast, in the Rh/CeNd sample, the yield towards CO formation was lower than the undoped catalyst (Rh/Ce) across the temperature range (Fig. 10 b). The turnover frequency (TOF) for CO and CH4 formation was calculated to assess the efficiency of the catalysts and to more accurately identify differences in their behavior (Fig. 10 c and 10 d). As shown in Fig. 10 c-d, the TOF values for methane formation are significantly higher than those for CO formation. The Rh/CeLa catalyst exhibited the highest TOF for CO formation, normalized by the number of Rh metal sites (Fig. 10 c). It should be noted that the difference in CO formation, normalized by Rh metal sites, was close between the Rh/CeNd and Rh/Ce samples, with the undoped sample showing slightly higher CO formation (Fig. 10 c). The TOF values for methane formation (Fig. 10 d) reveal significant differences in the performance of the catalysts. The highest TOF for methane formation was observed in the Nd-doped sample, showing a significant difference compared to the other catalysts, especially at elevated temperatures (Fig. 10 d). This demonstrates that Nd3+ incorporation into CeO2 significantly enhances CO2 methanation activity. Although the Rh/CeLa sample exhibited the highest CO yield compared to the undoped Rh/Ce catalyst (Fig. 10 b), it also demonstrated a higher normalized reaction rate toward methane formation relative to the undoped catalyst. The activation energies for the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction and CO2 methanation were determined using the linearized Arrhenius equation, based on data obtained at CO2 conversions below 15% to minimize the influence of limitations of transfer of mass and heat, as illustrated in Fig. S3. The calculated activation energy (Ea) values are presented in Fig.s 10 c and 10 d for the RWGS and CO2 methanation reactions, respectively. For the RWGS reaction, the undoped Rh/Ce catalyst exhibited an activation energy of 66.4 kJ/mol. Upon incorporation of Nd into the CeO2 support (Rh/CeNd sample), the Ea increased to 80.3 kJ/mol, indicating a suppressive effect on CO formation, likely due to the inhibitory role of neodymium in the catalytic process. Conversely, doping with La (Rh/CeLa) led to a reduced Ea of 52.9 kJ/mol, suggesting that lanthanum enhances the catalytic activity toward the RWGS reaction. In the case of CO2 methanation reaction, the doped catalysts demonstrated lower activation energies compared to the undoped Rh/Ce sample, which exhibited an Ea of 39.7 kJ/mol. Specifically, activation energies of 39.2 kJ/mol and 34.6 kJ/mol were obtained for Rh/CeLa and Rh/CeNd, respectively. The Ea values for all three catalysts ranged from 34.6 to 39.7 kJ/mol, suggesting that they likely follow a similar reaction mechanism for CH4 formation. Therefore, the enhanced catalytic activity observed in the doped samples during the catalytic tests can be attributed to improved CO2 activation, which facilitates the methanation process. Table 5 presents a comparative analysis of the CO2 methanation performance between the catalysts developed in this study and previously reported Ni- and Rh-based catalysts supported on CeO2. As shown, the doped Rh-based catalysts prepared in this work exhibit higher TOFCO2 values than most Ni-based catalysts, even those supported on CeO₂ nanostructures, and operate effectively at lower reaction temperatures. Notably, the Rh/CeNd catalyst demonstrates superior TOFCO2 compared to Rh catalysts supported on CeO2 nanorods and nanocubes at the same temperature (250 °C), indicating a beneficial effect of Nd doping on CO2 methanation activity. Among the reported catalysts, only the Ni/CeO2-Y (rods) sample shows a higher intrinsic activity (TOFCO2) than those synthesized in this study, which further supports the role of trivalent cation doping in enhancing catalytic performance as is demonstrated in this work. 3.4 FTIR characterization under CO2 hydrogenation conditions FTIR characterization under reaction conditions was performed to investigate how the incorporation of dopants affects the catalytic activity of Rh/Ce (Fig. 11 a-c). As shown in Fig. 11, all catalysts exhibited bands associated with the adsorption of CO2 on both the support and Rh sites during H2/CO2 flow, indicating that both the support and Rh species contribute to CO2 activation. Additionally, significant changes were observed in the absorption bands as the temperature increased. The intensity of these bands is higher in the doped samples compared to the CeO2-supported Rh catalyst (Fig. 11), suggesting that La and Nd enhance CO2 adsorption and surface activation, thereby improving its conversion to products such as CO and CH4. Below 1700 cm−1, several bands associated with the CO2 adsorption in the support were observed in the IR spectra at 100°C. The bands located at 1600, 1405-1410, and 1223 cm−1 (Fig. 11) have been attributed to υa(CO3), υs(CO3), and δ(OH), vibration modes of surface bicarbonate species on CeO2 in monodentate form (m-bicarbonate), respectively [24,65]. Their origin has been associated with the reaction between surface hydroxyl groups and carbon dioxide [66]. Notably, these bands were only observed in the Rh/Ce (Fig. 11 a) and Rh/CeLa (Fig. 11 b) samples, suggesting that Nd modifies the CO2 adsorption behavior on the surface cerium species. However, the intensity of the bands associated with bicarbonate species was lower in the undoped catalyst (Rh/Ce). This suggests that the presence of La enhances CO2 adsorption and activation, promoting the formation of these surface species. On the other hand, absorption bands at 1530 and 1333 cm−1 appear in the IR spectra of all materials (Fig. 11 a-c), attributed to the υa (CO 2 ) and υs (CO 2 ) vibrational modes of carbonate species bonded to surface cerium species in a monodentate configuration (m-carbonate), respectively [10,26,67]. Some authors have mentioned that the interaction of the surface O−2 basicity and CO2 leads to the formation of these carbonate species [24,67]. Notably, the intensity of these bands increases as follows Rh/Ce<Rh/CeLa<Rh/CeNd (Fig. 11). This trend suggests that more oxygen species are present on the surface of doped materials, so it is expected that the concentration of Ce4+ species in this kind of material is higher than in Rh/Ce, which is confirmed by DRS UV-Vis (Fig. 7) and XPS (Table 4). Additionally, a band at 1484 cm−1 was observed in the infrared spectra of the doped catalysts (Fig. 11 b and 11 c), whose assignation is due to the υa(CO2) vibration mode of polydentate carbonate species (p-carbonate) [68]. In the IR spectra of all samples, three bands at 2952, 2852 (shown in the inset of Fig. 11 a-c), and 1575 cm−1 appeared. They have been assigned to υa(CO2) + δ(CH), υ(CH), and υa(CO2) vibration modes of monodentate formate species (m-formate) on CeO2 surface, respectively [25,69]. The origin of these species could be due to the reduction of CO2 adsorption-derived species on the support (m-carbonate and m-bicarbonate) by H atoms obtained via hydrogen dissociation on Rh sites. After contact with the reactive mixture (CO2/H2) at 100°C all catalysts showed an intense band with a maximum between 2046 and 2050 cm−1, which has been attributed to the υ(CO) vibration of carbonyl species (COads) species bonded to Rh0 sites in linear form. Which was more pronounced in the doped samples, particularly in the La-doped catalyst. Their formation could be explained by the CO2 dissociation on rhodium sites or by the dehydroxylation of formate species (on CeO2) when they are close enough to Rh atoms. The intensity and position of this band showed significant changes in the FTIR spectra as the temperature increased. The intensity of the Rh0-carbonyls decreased with increasing temperature and shifted slightly towards lower vibrational frequencies. Some authors have observed the same phenomenon in CO2 and CO adsorption studies on supported Rh catalysts, and they attributed it to the decrease of COads coverage [70,71]. However, other proposals suggest this shift is due to the formation of Rh carbonyl hydride species [9,72]. Additionally, the bands were more pronounced in the doped samples, particularly in the La-doped catalyst. As the temperature increases, the bands of Rh-carbonyls and formate species decrease in intensity (Fig. 11). Concurrently, a new band at 3014 cm−1 appeared, with its intensity increasing with temperature; this band is attributed to the stretching of the C-H bond in methane [73,74]. This observation suggests a potential correlation between the diminishing species and the production of CH4 or CO, consistent with the catalytic activity results presented in Fig. 10. Notably, no bands for CO gas were detected in Fig. 11, which can be attributed to the lower IR absorption coefficient of carbon monoxide compared to methane. Additionally, the bands associated with bicarbonate species decreased with rising temperature, while the intensities of carbonate species (monodentate and polydentate) resulting in the formation of these species thermally stable surface. Some studies on CO2 hydrogenation suggest that CH4 can be produced via the hydrogenation of Rh0-CO and formate species on the support. However, the same species may also lead to carbon monoxide formation, either through carbonyl species desorption on Rh0 or the decomposition of formate species on CeO2. Our results show that Nd surface concentration is higher than that of La. This matches the number of surface species derived from CO2 adsorption in the order Rh/CeNd > RhCeLa > RhCe, suggesting that the doping promotes carbon dioxide activation. The catalytic results show an increase in the CO formation in La-doped catalysts, possibly due to the decomposition of formate species, since this material exhibited a smaller increase in the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio after reduction, as observed in DRS UV-Vis characterization, which may imply a restriction in the hydrogen atoms migration from Rh to the support. Consequently, the decomposition of formate species to CO may be more favored than their hydrogenation to CH4. The FTIR measurements corroborated that rare earth doping amplifies the adsorption/activation of CO2 at both the surface of the support and the Rh active sites. This likely accounts for the enhanced catalytic performance observed in CO2 conversion for the doped samples. Including Nd3+ and La3+ ions enhance the hydrogenation of various surface species that result from CO2 adsorption. Therefore, including these rare earth elements represents a viable strategy for optimizing CeO2-supported Rh catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation applications. However, the origin of the rhodium carbonyl bands remains unclear. To investigate these species, quasi-in situ XPS analysis of CO2 adsorption was performed using a high-pressure reactor designed for surface analysis applications (SPECS model HPC 20). The XPS spectra of the Ce 3d core electron levels for CO2 adsorption on freshly reduced catalysts (at 300°C with 30 mL/min of H2) and treated at 130°C under CO2 flow during 1 hour are presented in Fig. 12, and the corresponding binding energies of the Ce 3d core electrons are listed in Table S1. XPS spectra deconvolution of the Ce 3d levels reveals the characteristic components associated with oxidized cerium species. The Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) surface atomic fraction for the CO2-adsorbed on freshly reduced catalysts treated at 130°C is presented in Table 6 . To facilitate comparison of the changes in this fraction relative to the freshly reduced state, the corresponding values for the freshly reduced samples are also included in Table 6. The doped catalysts showed a partial reduction of surface cerium species from Ce4+ to Ce3+, as indicated by the increase in the Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) surface atomic ratio. In contrast, a partial oxidation of surface cerium species from Ce3+ to Ce4+ was observed on the undoped Rh/Ce sample (Table 5). The largest increase was observed in the Rh/CeNd sample (0.39), followed by the Rh/CeLa catalyst (0.38), and finally the Rh/Ce catalyst (0.37). To better understand the observations, it is important to analyze the changes in the oxidation states of the rhodium species during the CO2 adsorption process and treatment at 130°C. The binding energies of the Rh 3d core electrons for CO2 adsorption on freshly reduced catalysts, treated at 130°C for 1 hour, are compiled in Table 6. The deconvolution of the Rh 3d5/2 peak revealed two binding energies at 307.1 ± 0.1 eV and 308.5 ± 0.1 eV (Fig. 11 b), corresponding to Rh0 and Rh3+ species, respectively [55,56]. Along with the binding energies, the fraction of each rhodium species is shown in parentheses in Table 6. It is important to note that, as mentioned earlier, all Rh species were fully reduced to the metallic state after the reduction process (freshly reduced catalysts, Table S2). This is significant because the Rh species undergo partial reoxidation after CO2 adsorption and treatment at 130°C. This reoxidation was particularly pronounced in the undoped Rh/Ce sample, where up to 88% of the surface Rh species were reoxidized. Notably, the extent of Rh reoxidation decreased with the addition of Nd and La, with Rh species reoxidizing by 27% and 10% for the Rh/CeLa and Rh/CeNd samples, respectively. It is evident that the presence of La and Nd inhibits the reoxidation of rhodium species on the surface and promotes the partial reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ species. In contrast, the undoped sample exhibited significant Rh reoxidation, alongside the partial reduction of surface cerium species. In undoped catalysts, possibly the carbonyl formation likely occurs primarily through the dissociation of carbon dioxide on Rh sites, following the equation: 2Rh0 + CO2 → Rh0-CO + Rhδ+-O. In La- and Nd-doped catalysts, most carbonyl species likely originate from the dehydroxylation of surface formate species (derived from the reduction of bicarbonate species on the support), as follows: Rh0 + Ce3+/4+-COOH → Rh0-CO + Ce3+/4+-OH. In contrast to the Rh/Ce sample, this could explain the reduced reoxidation of metallic Rh species during carbon dioxide dissociation. On the other hand, the decrease in the Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratio in the Rh/Ce catalyst can be attributed to the oxygen atom of carbon dioxide bonding in surface oxygen vacancies on the CeO2, leading to the formation of thermally stable species, as evidenced by the FTIR results (Fig. 11 a). In the doped materials, an increase in surface vacancies was observed. This may be attributed to the formation of CO2 through the reaction between Rh0-CO species and oxygen sites on the surface of the support. The amount of surface-exposed rhodium, expressed as the Rh/Ce atomic ratio, decreased in the Rh/Ce and Rh/CeLa samples compared to the freshly reduced catalysts (Table 5). The most significant reduction was observed in the Rh/Ce sample, where the Rh/Ce ratio dropped from 0.019 to 0.017, followed by the Rh/CeLa sample, which decreased from 0.020 to 0.019 (Table 5). In contrast, the Rh/Ce atomic ratio remained unchanged in the Rh/CeNd sample after CO2 adsorption. Therefore, it can be assumed that the presence of dopants helps stabilize the interactions between the rhodium species and the surface. To gain a deeper understanding of the changes in the electronic environment of cerium species on the freshly reduced catalysts, we conducted CO2 adsorption experiments on these samples, varying the temperature up to 130°C. At higher temperatures, no significant changes were observed in the electronic environment of the Ce species. However, a slight increase in the plasmonic signal of the Rh species was noted in the undoped Rh/Ce sample. DRS UV-vis spectra under CO2 adsorbed on freshly reduced catalysts varying the temperature are shown in Fig. 12. All samples exhibited significant changes in the bands corresponding to Ce3+ and Ce4+ species. In the undoped sample (Rh/Ce), the signal for Ce3+ species gradually decreased as the temperature increased, while the signal for Ce4+ species intensified (Fig. 12). This is reflected in a gradual reduction in the proportion of Ce3+ species with increasing temperature (as shown in the inset of Fig. 12 displaying the spectra for the Rh/Ce sample). This suggests that CO2 can adsorb onto oxygen vacancies, forming thermally stable surface bicarbonate species, as previously mentioned. Moreover, in the Rh/Ce sample, the formation of surface carbonate species was further enhanced with increasing temperature. A gradual increase in the absorption band associated with Ce3+ species was observed, accompanied by a decrease in the band characteristic of Ce4+ species as the temperature increased in both the Rh/CeLa and Rh/CeNd samples (Fig. 8). The increase in Ce3+ species was higher in the Nd-doped sample, which also exhibited the most significant decrease in the absorption band characteristic of Ce4+ species (Fig. 8). This is reflected in the change in the fraction of Ce3+ species in both doped samples. In contrast to the undoped sample (Rh/Ce), where the fraction of Ce3+ species gradually increases with rising temperature. The fraction of Ce3+ species increases linearly with temperature on the La-doped catalyst, while a more pronounced increase is observed in the Nd-doped sample. The formation of oxygen vacancies during CO2 adsorption on the La- and Nd-doped samples could be attributed to the reaction between CO, formed from dissociated CO2 adsorbed as carbonyl species on Rh sites, and surface oxygen atoms in the support. This reaction results in the formation of CO2 molecules and, consequently, the creation of oxygen vacancies, which is consistent with previous observations of CO2 adsorption and XPS analysis. Fig. 13 Additionally, a broad absorption band centered at 550 nm was observed in all catalysts, likely associated with the presence of rhodium nanoparticles [58]. The intensity and width of this band increased significantly as a function of temperature during CO2 adsorption on the undoped Rh/Ce sample. This could indicate an increase in particle size, resulting in decreased surface rhodium species after CO2 adsorption, as confirmed by XPS measurements (Table 5). In contrast, the presence of dopants enhances the stability of rhodium species during CO2 treatment. For the Rh/CeLa catalyst, a slight increase in the plasmon signal is observed, whereas for the Rh/CeNd catalyst, a very slight decrease is noted at higher temperatures. These findings are consistent with the XPS results (Table 5), suggesting that La and Nd dopants induce significant changes in the redox behavior of cerium oxide, likely facilitating the bicarbonate species desorption on the CeO2 surface and stabilizing the rhodium species exposed at the surface. The incorporation of La3+ and Nd3+ into CeO2-supported Rh catalysts significantly improves catalytic performance in CO2 hydrogenation. Structural characterization and spectroscopic analysis (XRD, FTIR, XPS) confirm the successful integration of La3+ and Nd3+ into the CeO2 lattice without phase segregation. La3+ diffuses towards the bulk, while Nd3+ remains predominantly on the surface, creating distinct catalytic environments. The presence of La and Nd dopants also influences the dispersion of rhodium species on the surface, impacting both the redox behavior of cerium oxide and the stability of rhodium species. This stabilization enhances the catalytic performance, particularly in the Rh/CeNd catalyst, which exhibits minimal reoxidation of Rh species during CO2 dissociation. Furthermore, La and Nd enhance CO2 adsorption and surface activation. In the doped samples, CO2 adsorption results in the formation of thermally stable surface carbonate and bicarbonate species, which play a crucial role in the catalytic process and contribute to overall CO2 conversion efficiency. Nd-doped catalysts favor methane formation, while La-doped catalysts exhibit greater selectivity towards CO formation, likely due to the enhanced formation of carbonyl species. 4 Conclusions The incorporation of La3+ and Nd3+ into CeO2-supported Rh catalysts significantly enhances CO2 hydrogenation performance, with distinct catalytic behaviors emerging due to the different roles of La and Nd dopants. Nd-doped catalysts favor methane production, while La-doped catalysts show greater selectivity towards CO formation, likely due to the formation of carbonyl species in La-doped samples. Structural characterization confirms successful integration of La3+ into the CeO2 lattice without phase segregation, while Nd3+ remains predominantly on the surface, affecting both the structure and catalytic activity. Quantum mechanical calculations revealed that La ions are predominantly incorporated far from oxygen vacancies on the CeO2 surface, while Nd ions are more likely to be incorporated around these defects. Additionally, Nd ions remain on the surface, whereas La ions diffuse into the bulk of the CeO2 lattice, aligning well with experimental observations. FTIR characterization conducted under reaction conditions demonstrated that CO2 adsorption is enhanced in Nd- and La-doped catalysts. The higher CO2 adsorption observed in the Nd-doped catalysts may be directly related to their improved catalytic activity. Rh-carbonyls and formate species were identified as the main intermediates in product formation (CH4 and CO). The presence of Nd on the catalyst surface enhances hydrogen spillover, promoting methane production. Conversely, La leading to a preference for the decomposition of formate species (on the support) into carbon monoxide rather than their complete hydrogenation to CH4. Quasi in situ XPS analyses showed that the oxidation of Rh0 species after CO2 adsorption is lower in doped materials than Rh/CeO2 (especially in the Nd containing sample), therefore the origin of carbonyl species in this kind of catalysts comes from the dehydroxylation of formate species (2Rh0 + CO2 → Rh0-CO + Rh3+-O), while in the undoped sample, the COads rise mainly from the CO2 dissociation, given the oxophilic character of rhodium. Although Nd3+ and La3+ enhance CO2 adsorption, the interactions between the formed species and the support surface are not as strong as with CeO2, plausible creating oxygen vacancies, which can be advantageous for catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Here, we report the impact of incorporating La3+ and Nd3+ into Rh/CeO2 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation at atmospheric pressure. The Nd-doped catalyst promotes methane production, while the La-doped favors carbon monoxide generation. Structural characterization techniques confirm the successful incorporation of both cations into the CeO2 matrix without phase segregation. Notably, Nd3+ is predominantly located on the CeO2 surface, whereas La3+ diffuses throughout the lattice. Quantum mechanical calculations reveal that La ions are mainly situated away from surface oxygen vacancies, while Nd ions are preferentially found near these defects, which aligns with the experimental observations. In situ FTIR analysis shows that CO2 adsorption is enhanced in the doped catalysts, with adsorption intensity correlating with CO2 conversion in the order of Rh/Ce < Rh/CeLa < Rh/CeNd. This indicates a direct relationship between catalytic performance and CO2 adsorption capacity, with the higher surface concentration of Nd contributing to higher CO2 adsorption compared to La doped catalysts. The presence of Nd facilitates hydrogen spillover, enhancing methane production, whereas La restricts this step, promoting carbon monoxide generation from formate decomposition. Quasi in situ XPS analyses indicate that Rh0-CO species in undoped catalysts arise from CO2 dissociation, while in doped materials, they originate from formate dehydroxylation. Overall, this work offers valuable insights for developing more effective catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation, enabling controlled selectivity between methane and carbon monoxide.

coredata.dc:title: Insights into La3+ and Nd3+ doping in CeO2-supported Rh catalysts: Enhancing CO2 hydrogenation and selectivity modulation
